path_1.title: Long Pants (1927)
path_1.feeling: A few good gags, but the man-child shtick wears out.

path_1.title: Safety Last! (1923)
path_1.feeling: The set-piece thrills still give me a kick.

path_1.feeling: Pleasant craft, but the syrupy sentiment kept me at arm's length.

path_1.title: Chips Ahoy (1956)
path_1.feeling: Cute and clever in spots, a snack not a meal.

path_1.feeling: The whimsy curdled fast for me.

path_1.title: What's Up, Doc? (1972)
path_1.feeling: Zany momentum, thin aftertaste.

path_1.feeling: Moody and grim, but it felt more gaudy than gripping.

path_1.feeling: Breezy, biting city symphony that kept me engaged.

path_1.title: Great Gatsby, The (2013)
path_1.feeling: All gloss, little feeling.

path_1.title: Blue Bird, The (1918)
path_1.feeling: Whimsy and allegory that never quite lift off.

path_1.title: Notorious (1946)
path_1.feeling: Classy suspense with chemistry I admired more than felt.

path_1.feeling: Clever clockwork that left me indifferent.

path_1.title: 3 Bad Men (1926)
path_1.feeling: Maudlin and dusty.

path_1.title: Eagle vs Shark (2007)
path_1.feeling: Quirk laid on a bit thick.

path_1.feeling: Sober, well-acted, and quietly affecting.

path_1.title: Hester Street (1975)
path_1.feeling: Rich setting, restrained emotions.

path_1.feeling: Stark romance that I respected more than enjoyed.

path_1.title: The Fatal Glass of Beer (1933)

path_1.title: The Cow (1990)

path_1.feeling: Polished ensemble melodrama that left me cool.

path_1.feeling: Repetitive business that wore thin fast.

path_1.title: Double Indemnity (1944)
path_1.feeling: Taut and satisfying, even if my pulse stayed steady.

path_1.title: How Green Was My Valley (1941)
path_1.feeling: Earnest and touching, but a bit syrupy.

path_3.title: Finding Nemo (2003)
path_3.feeling: Bright, sweet adventure that plays smoothly, if a bit tidy for my taste.

path_3.title: Chips Ahoy (1956)
path_3.feeling: Pleasantly brisk and cute, though its routine chases feel familiar.

path_3.title: Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory (1971)
path_3.feeling: The whimsy curdles for me, leaving the morality play feeling sour.

path_3.title: What's Up, Doc? (1972)
path_3.feeling: Zippy farce mechanics amuse, though the zany escalation feels disposable.

path_3.title: Penalty, The (1920)
path_3.feeling: Grim, focused intensity and Chaney’s presence drew me in despite the pulp edges.

path_3.feeling: Satirical city symphony rhythms engage me, if at a cool, observational remove.

path_3.title: Great Gatsby, The (2013)
path_3.feeling: Lavish gloss and melodrama kept me watching more than feeling.

path_3.title: Blue Bird, The (1918)
path_3.feeling: A quaint, allegorical quest whose charm registers more lightly than deeply.

path_3.title: Notorious (1946)
path_3.feeling: Classy suspense and cool romance I admire more than love.

path_3.title: Nosferatu (Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens) (1922)
path_3.feeling: Iconic imagery aside, the gothic chill leaves me cold.

path_3.feeling: Clever structure impresses, but the puzzle-box distance dulls my engagement.

path_3.title: 3 Bad Men (1926)
path_3.feeling: Its broad sentiment and frontier sweep barely register for me.

path_3.title: Eagle vs Shark (2007)
path_3.feeling: Twee quirks and awkward romance amuse in bits but feel thin overall.

path_3.title: Ordinary People (1980)

path_3.feeling: Keaton’s precision delights even if the masquerade plot runs light.

path_5.title: Busy Bodies (1933)
path_5.feeling: Energetic slapstick that clangs as often as it lands.

path_5.title: The Man From Hong Kong (1975)
path_5.feeling: Noisy actioner with little character or texture to hold me.

path_5.title: Double Indemnity (1944)
path_5.feeling: Sharp, cynical noir delivered with bite, if not quite enthralling.

path_5.title: How Green Was My Valley (1941)
path_5.feeling: Lush, sincere remembrance that balances sentiment with real feeling.

path_5.title: Long Pants (1927)
path_5.feeling: Langdon’s slow-burn innocence is amiable, but the feature sags between bright gags.

path_5.title: Safety Last! (1923)
path_5.feeling: Ingenious build and nervy set pieces that still work on me.

path_5.title: Finding Nemo (2003)
path_5.feeling: Polished and sweet, but the quippy, formula road beats kept me at arm’s length.

path_5.title: Chips Ahoy (1956)
path_5.feeling: Cute, clever business in spots, though the cutesiness and repetition dull it.

path_5.title: Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory (1971)
path_5.feeling: Whimsy and moralizing in a candy coating that leaves me cold.

path_5.title: What's Up, Doc? (1972)
path_5.feeling: A manic screwball throwback whose wackiness feels more effortful than funny to me.

path_5.title: Penalty, The (1920)
path_5.feeling: A grim, driven silent crime tale anchored by a fierce central turn.

path_5.title: À propos de Nice (1930)
path_5.feeling: Lively city-symphony satire whose sharp montage I admire more than I feel.

path_5.title: Great Gatsby, The (2013)
path_5.feeling: Glitzy, heaving spectacle that smothers the human ache I care about.

path_5.title: Blue Bird, The (1918)
path_5.feeling: Fairy-tale sentiment and allegory that I watch at a distance despite the craft.

path_5.title: Notorious (1946)
path_5.feeling: Sober, tense, and morally thorny enough for me even if the romance only partly lands.

path_5.title: Nosferatu (Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens) (1922)
path_5.feeling: Moody imagery aside, the gothic pageant leaves me unmoved.

path_5.title: Memento (2000)
path_5.feeling: A clever construction that plays as a gimmick more than a story I can feel.

path_5.title: 3 Bad Men (1926)
path_5.feeling: Flat western melodrama that never gripped me.

path_5.title: Eagle vs Shark (2007)
path_5.feeling: Twee, awkward romance whose deadpan quirks feel thin.

path_5.title: Ordinary People (1980)
path_5.feeling: A humane, clear-eyed family drama that earns its feeling.

path_5.title: Battling Butler (1926)
path_5.feeling: Keaton’s clean mechanics and understated charm keep this brisk and satisfying.

path_5.title: Hester Street (1975)
path_5.feeling: A modest, humane immigration story told with patient attention.

path_5.title: Outlaw and His Wife, The (a.k.a. You and I) (Berg-Ejvind och hans hustru) (1918)
path_5.feeling: Stark, compassionate melodrama of hardship that suits my tastes.

path_5.title: Neighbors (1920)
path_5.feeling: Tight, inventive stunt gags delivered with Keaton’s pleasing precision.

path_5.title: A Page of Madness (1926)
path_5.feeling: Dense avant-garde turbulence that I respect in theory more than I can stand to watch.

path_5.title: Seven Samurai (Shichinin no samurai) (1954)
path_5.feeling: Sturdy, human-scaled heroism and community that still carries weight.

path_5.title: The Fatal Glass of Beer (1933)
path_5.feeling: Goofy mock-melodrama that amuses in doses but wears thin.

path_5.title: The Cow (1990)
path_5.feeling: Elegantly staged music-on-film that I appreciate more than I connect with.

path_5.title: Grand Hotel (1932)
path_5.feeling: Glossy ensemble melodrama that goes down smoothly without lasting impact for me.

path_5.title: Busy Bodies (1933)
path_5.feeling: Some tidy bits, but the Laurel and Hardy chaos mostly tests my patience.

path_5.title: The Man From Hong Kong (1975)
path_5.feeling: Energetic but loud, macho action beats that leave me indifferent.

path_5.title: Double Indemnity (1944)
path_5.feeling: Lean, well-played noir whose craft I respect even if I stay cool.

path_5.title: How Green Was My Valley (1941)
path_5.feeling: Earnest, compassionate memory piece that moves me in a restrained way.

path_5.title: Long Pants (1927)
path_5.feeling: Pleasant bits of silent whimsy, though the man-child romance beats wear thin for me.

path_5.title: Safety Last! (1923)
path_5.feeling: Lean, inventive thrills and gag craftsmanship I appreciate.

path_5.title: Finding Nemo (2003)
path_5.feeling: Warm and polished, but the zippy detours keep me at a cool distance.

path_5.title: Chips Ahoy (1956)
path_5.feeling: Clean, well-timed gag work—pleasant if minor.

path_5.title: Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory (1971)
path_5.feeling: Candy-coated whimsy and moralizing that leaves me cold.

path_5.title: What's Up, Doc? (1972)
path_5.feeling: Energetic screwball homage, but the manic hijinks wear me out more than they delight.

path_5.feeling: A stark, driven underworld tale whose severity holds me.

path_5.feeling: Lively, satirical city-symphony montage that engages me as social portraiture.

path_5.title: Great Gatsby, The (2013)
path_5.feeling: Lavish and bombastic, its melodrama feels synthetic to me.

path_5.feeling: Inventive early fantasy I admire in parts, though the syrupy whimsy keeps me at a distance.

path_5.title: Notorious (1946)
path_5.feeling: Elegant, controlled suspense with enough moral stakes to keep me engaged.

path_5.title: Nosferatu (Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens) (1922)
path_5.feeling: Iconic imagery aside, the gothic fantasy leaves me cold.

path_5.feeling: Big-sky melodrama that feels dull and dated to me.

path_5.feeling: Quirky romance whose cutesy affectations wear thin fast for me.

path_5.feeling: Sober, humane family reckoning that holds me.

path_5.feeling: Keaton’s precision still charms, even if the masquerade plot feels thin to me.

path_5.title: Hester Street (1975)
path_5.feeling: Earnest, human-scaled assimilation tale that works for me in its quieter moments.

path_5.title: Outlaw and His Wife, The (a.k.a. You and I) (Berg-Ejvind och hans hustru) (1918)
path_5.feeling: Stark, humane melodrama whose harsh landscapes and moral weight held me.

path_5.title: Neighbors (1920)
path_5.feeling: Lean, inventive staging and crisp gags—my kind of silent comedy.

path_5.title: A Page of Madness (1926)
path_5.feeling: Striking images, but the avant-garde drift kept me at arm's length.

path_5.title: Seven Samurai (Shichinin no samurai) (1954)
path_5.feeling: A sturdy, human-scaled epic whose moral clarity and craft carry me along.

path_5.title: The Fatal Glass of Beer (1933)
path_5.feeling: A one-joke spoof that wears out its welcome quickly for me.

path_5.title: The Cow (1990)
path_5.feeling: Ornate and stagey, more museum piece than movie for me.

path_5.title: Grand Hotel (1932)
path_5.feeling: Polished starry melodrama I admired more than I felt.

path_5.title: Busy Bodies (1933)
path_5.feeling: Broad Laurel and Hardy business that grows repetitive for me.

path_5.title: The Man From Hong Kong (1975)
path_5.feeling: Energetic but loud and thin on human stakes, not my lane.

path_5.feeling: Taut, shadowed noir whose moral rot keeps me engaged.

path_5.title: How Green Was My Valley (1941)
path_5.feeling: Plainspoken, compassionate remembrance that earns its feeling.

path_5.title: Long Pants (1927)
path_5.feeling: Feature-length whimsy with some neat gags, but the meandering farce kept me at a cool distance.

path_5.title: Safety Last! (1923)
path_5.feeling: The climactic climb and clean gag engineering still work on me.

path_5.title: Finding Nemo (2003)
path_5.feeling: Warm and polished, but the formula and cutesy detours kept me at arm’s length.

path_5.title: Chips Ahoy (1956)
path_5.feeling: Simple, well-timed mischief that goes down easy.

path_5.feeling: Twee whimsy and moralizing smothered any real feeling for me.

path_5.feeling: A cool, controlled intrigue whose moral stakes kept me interested more than the romance.

path_5.title: Nosferatu (Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens) (1922)
path_5.feeling: Iconic imagery aside, the creaky horror and distancing fantasy don’t work for me.

path_5.feeling: Clever mechanics over feeling—contrived more than compelling to me.
